items.title: Yoplait Yop yogurt drinks recalled in Canada over plastic contamination fears
items.summary_auto: Many of Yoplait's yogurts have been pulled from Canadian shelves after the company shared fears over pieces of plastic in some products.

items.title: Bolsonaro claims 'hallucinations' led the ex-Brazil president to tamper with ankle monitor
items.summary_auto: On his first full day in jail, former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro told a judge on Sunday he had violated his ankle monitoring the day before while under house arrest because of a nervous breakdown and hallucinations caused by a change in his medication.

items.title: Carney, Modi agree to launch negotiations on new Canada-India trade deal: source
50 schoolchildren escape captivity in Nigeria, 253 students and 12 teachers still being held
items.summary_auto: Fifty of the 303 schoolchildren abducted from a Catholic school in north-central Nigeria’s Niger state have escaped captivity and are now with their families, the school authority said Sunday, bringing relief to some distraught families after one of the largest school abductions in Nigeria’s history.

items.title: Israel says it killed a senior Hezbollah official in first strike on Beirut in months
items.summary_auto: Israel carried out an airstrike on a southern Beirut suburb on Sunday, saying it killed Hezbollah’s chief of staff Haytham Tabtabai and warning the Iran-backed militant group not to rearm and rebuild a year after their latest war.

items.title: Alberta food banks grapple with high cost of free beef
items.summary_auto: Rural Alberta food banks are seeking provincial funding to support a program that sees cattle producers donate animals to organizations that feed people in need.

items.title: Small Sask. town rallies to preserve historic bridge a decade after its closure
items.summary_auto: The town of Saint Louis, Sask., has rallied together to save a historic bridge with a century-old legacy. The former railway bridge is now a walkway designed to teach people about the community's rich Métis culture.

items.title: Trailblazing N.L. pitcher Jaida Lee drafted in new Women’s Pro Baseball League
items.summary_auto: Nineteen-year-old Jaida Lee of St. John's was drafted to play for New York in the Women’s Pro Baseball League on Thursday night.

items.title: Plug-in polluter? Why Canada may need to rethink 'transition' EV
I'm an Acadian at heart even if my accent marks me as an outsider
items.summary_auto: Bailey Ross has devoted himself to speaking French and promoting Acadian culture. But feeling like he belonged and could call himself Acadian came much later in life.

items.title: Retailers feel Black Friday pressure as Canadians expected to tighten their spending
items.summary_auto: With trade uncertainty, tariffs and rising prices, Canadian shoppers are expected to pull back this holiday season. Retailers are offering weeks-long discounts —and for some, their first Black Friday deals ever — in the hope of enticing people to spend.

items.title: 3 ways Canada and China can reset their relations in Trump's new trade world
items.summary_auto: As Canada starts to diversify its ties with other countries amidst an increasingly unpredictable and unreliable relationship with the U.S., its pivot toward China, in particular, will need to be strategic: the work must be done while balancing the risks and strengthening the country internally.

items.title: How the wonderful women of Oz pull back the curtain on L. Frank Baum’s feminism
items.summary_auto: The Wonderful Wizard of Oz, first released 125 years ago, is a seemingly simple story of friendship, self reliance and longing for home continues to speak to us. But another theme shimmers a bit deeper below the surface: feminism, in a world powered by its women, witches and queens.

items.title: Businesses welcome changes to Canada's greenwashing laws, but environmentalists aren't happy
items.summary_auto: Laws about greenwashing — making a false or misleading statement about the environmental benefits of a product — will remain on the books, but the Liberal government has said it will be making changes aimed at offering businesses more certainty about what runs afoul of the law.

items.title: Greenwashing laws are changing. Businesses are relieved, but environmentalists have concerns
items.summary_auto: Laws about greenwashing — making a false or misleading statement about the environmental benefits of a product — will remain on the books, but the Liberal government has said it will be making changes aimed at offering businesses more certainty about what runs afoul of the law.

items.title: Why some young people are investing based on vibes, not research
items.summary_auto: Some millennial and Gen Z Canadians believe it's harder to build wealth now than it was for their parents. So they're adopting more risk-taking investment strategies. Some say it's the only thing they think will help them get ahead financially.

items.title: Here's what happens when airline passengers have a medical emergency mid-flight
items.summary_auto: In-flight medical emergencies happen roughly once every 212 flights, according to recent research. Experts say that airlines have clear protocols in place to respond to in-flight medical emergencies, with access to trained physicians who can provide ground support in the event that flight crew aren't able to connect with a volunteer medical professional on board.
